Ibn-Fakhruddin Anju, author of the "Farhang Jahángiri," vide Jamal-uddín Husain Anjú.

Ibn-Farat, author of the Geographical Memoirs of Egypt.

Ibn-Farghani, Shaikh Abú Bakr Wasiti, a saint, who died about 320 A.H.

Ibn-Fourak, vide Fourak.

Ibn-Ghayas, vide Kamál-uddín Muḥammad Khwaja.

Ibn-Hajar, Shahab-uddin, son of 'Alí 'Uskálaní, an Arabian author who wrote more than a hundred books, among which are "Lisán-ul-Mizán," and Asába. He died in 1449 A.D., 853 A.H., vide Shahab-uddin Abú'l Fazl 'Uskálaní.

Ibn-Hajar Yehsami or Yehthami, son of Badr-uddin, author of the work called "Sa-wálik Muhríka," and several other books. He died in 1566 A.D., 974 A.H.

Ibn-Hajib, an Arabian author of several works. He died at Alexandria in the year 1248 A.D., 648 A.H. He is the author of the two commentaries called "Káfía and Shafá."

Ibn-Hanbal, whose proper name is Abú 'Abdulláh Ahmad-ash-Shaibání-al-Marwáni, but generally known by the name of Ibn-Hanbal, was the founder of the fourth Sunni sect. The learned doctor, who was a pupil of Sháfi'i's, strenuously upheld the opinion that the Kurán was uncreated, and that it had existed from all eternity. Since, however, it happened unfortunately that the Khalifa Al-Mustansir maintained the contrary doctrine, Ibn-Hanbal was greatly persecuted for his persistent opposition to that monarch's favorite belief. Vide Hanbal.

Ibn-Hanbalí, surname of Muhammad-bin-Ibráhím Hanbalí, author of the "Uddát-ul-Hásib-wa-Umdát-ul-Másáhib," a book of Arithmetic. He died 1663 A.D., 971 A.H., and is the author of several other works.

Ibn-Hasham, the author of the Sirát-ul-Rasul or Biography of the Prophet. His native place was Old Cairo, where he died in 828 A.D., 213 A.H. An abridgment of his work was made at Damascus in 1307 A.D., 707 A.H., by one Ahmad Ibn-Ibrahim.

Ibn-Hasham, son of Yúsf, author of several Arabic works, among which are "Toufích," "Sharah Álfá," &c. &c. He died 1361 A.D., 762 A.H.
Ibn-Hibban, whose proper name was Asr-uddin Muhammad, the son of Yúsa. Was the author of several works. He died at Damascus in the year 1344 A.D., 745 A.H.

Ibn-Hilal, also called 'Alá', is the author of a work, entitled "Minhaj-ul-Tálibín," which is also called "Tárikh 'Alá," and is dedicated to Sháh Shujá's Kirmani.

Ibn-Houbal, a celebrated physician and author, who died in the year 1213 A.D.

Ibn-Houkal, an Arabian, and author of the work, entitled "Akhkál-ul-Bilád," containing maps and geographical description of several countries, which he wrote in the year 977 A.D., 367 A.H.

Ibn-Humam, author of a Commentary on the Hidaya, entitled "Fatá-ul-Kadír," which is also called "Sharah Hidaya." He died in the year 1467 A.D., 861 A.H. He is also called Humam, which see.

Ibn-Husam, of Khawráf, surname of Shamsuddin Muhammad, author of an heroic poem in praise of 'Alí, containing the principal events of his life; his disputes, wars, &c., entitled "Kháwar Náma." He died 1470 A.D., 876 A.H.

Ibn-Ibad, surname of Abú'l Kasim Ismá'il, Káfí, who was wazir and first minister of state to the Sultán Muwáyad-ud-daula and Fakhruddaula of the race of Bóya. He died 995 A.D., 386 A.H., and is said to have left a library consisting of 112,000 volumes, and to have passed for the most generous and most liberal man of his time. He was also styled Káfí-ul-Káfí.

Ibn-Imad, a poet of Khurásán who flourished in the latter end of the 14th century of the Christian Era. He resided in Shiráz, and is author of a Diwán or a love-story, called "Dah Náma," in Persian.

Ibn-Jinni, whose proper name was Abú'l Fatha 'Usmán, a learned Musulmán, but blind of one eye. He died at Baghdad 1002 A.D., 392 A.H.

Ibn-Jouzi, vide Abú'l Farah-ibn-Jouzi.

Ibn-Kamal Pasha, surname of Mufti Shamsuddin Ahmad-bin-Sulaimán, author of the "Sharah Hadís-al-'Arbaín." He died 1533 A.D., 940 A.H.

Ibn-Kattas, surname of 'Ali-bin-Ja'far Sikkilí, an Arabian author, who died 1121 A.D., 515 A.H.

Ibn-Khaldun, the African philosopher. His name and titles are in Arabic: "Wali-uddin Abú Zaid 'Abdurrahman-bin-Muhammad-al-Hassani-al-Ishbili," but he is better known by the single patronymic name of Ibn Khaldún. His father summoned Khaldún was a native of Amazigh or Berber (in Africa), but his wife, descending from a family of the Arabian province Harrán, made her sons adopt the surname of Al-Harrání. He was born in Tunis in the year 1332 A.D., and passed his youth in Egypt. He then served a short time under Taimur, as chief justice at Damascus. He returned to Egypt where he became Supreme Judge, and died in the year 1406 A.D. His principal and most remarkable work is the History of the Arabs, the Persians, and the Berbers. The whole composition is commonly called Tarikh-ibn-Khaldún.

Ibn-Khallikan, whose full name is Shamsuddin Abú'l Abbás Ahmad-bin-Muhammad-bin-Abu Bakr ibn-Khallikan, drew his descent from a family of Balkh. This very eminent scholar and follower of Sháfi'i doctrines, was born at Arbelá, but resided at Damascus, where he had filled the place of chief Káfi till the year 1281 A.D., 680 A.H., when he was dismissed, and from that time till the day of his death he never went out of doors. He was a man of the greatest reputation for learning, versed in various sciences, and highly accomplished; he was a scholar, a poet, a compiler, and an historian. By his talents and writings, he merited the honorable title of "the most learned man," and the ablest historian. His celebrated Biographical work, called the Wafát-ul-Aiyán or deaths of eminent men, is the acme of perfection. This work was translated from the Arabic by Baron MacGucklin De Slane, Member of the Council of the Asiatic Society of Paris, &c., and published in 1843 A.D. This translation is a valuable work to those who wish to gain a knowledge of the legal literature of the Muhammadans, as he has added to the text numerous learned notes, replete with curious and interesting information relating to the Muhammadan law and lawyers. Ibn-Khallikan was born on Thursday the 22nd of September, 1211 A.D., 11th Rabí' II, 608 A.H., and died on Thursday the 31st of October, 1282 A.D., 26th Rajab, 681 A.H., aged 73 lunar years, in the Najjibía College at Damascus and was interred at Mount Kásídín.

Ibn-Khurdadbih, an historian, who died about the year 912 A.D. Vide Khurdádbih.

Ibn-Kutaiba, surname of Shaikh al-Imám Abú Muhammad Abdullah-bin-Muálim Dínwár, author of the "Ayún-ul-Akhbár," and many other works. He died 889 A.D., 267 A.H.

Ibn-Mája, whose proper name is Abú Abdul-láh Muhammad-bin-Yezíd-bin-Mája-al-Kázwíní, was the author of a collection of traditions, and of a commentary on the Kurán. The first, which is entitled "Kitáb-us-Sunan," is the sixth book of the Sunna, and is commonly called "Sunan Ibn-Mája." Ibn-Mája was born in the year 824 A.D., 203 A.H., and died in 886 A.D., 273 A.H.

Ibn-Maklá, waqf of the khalifá Káhir Biláh of Baghdad, whom, with the consent of other Umras, he deposed and having deprived him of sight, raised Al-Ráfí Biláh to the throne. Not long after, his hands and tongue were cut off by the order of Ráfí, because he had written a letter to the Khalifá's enemy without his knowledge, from which he died in the year 939 A.D., 327 A.H. Ibn-Maklá is the inventor of the present Arabic character which was afterwards improved by Ibn-Bauwáb.

Ibn-Marduyá, commonly called so, but his proper name is Abú Bakr. He is the author of the work "Mustakharjí Bihkáfi" and of a commentary and history. He died 410 A.H.

Ibn-Malik, vide Abú Abdulláh-ibn-Málík.

Ibn-Muallim, vide Shaikh Muftid.

Ibn-Rajáb, vide Zain-uddin-bin-Ahmad.

Ibn-Bashid, surname of Abú'l Walíd Muham-mad-bin-Ahmad, whom the Europeans call Avverroes and Avén Rosch, was one of the most subtile philosophers that ever appeared among the Arabians. He was born at Corduba in Spain, where his father held the office of high priest and chief judge, under the emperor of Morocco. His knowledge of law, divinity, mathematics, and astrology was very extensive, and to this was added the theory rather than the practice of medicine. On the death of his father, he was appointed to succeed him. Falling
under the suspicion of heresy, he was deprived of his posts and thrown into prison from whence he was at last delivered and reinstated in his office of judge. He wrote a treatise on the art of physic, an Epitome of Ptolemy's Almagest, a treatise on astrology, and many amorous verses; but when he grew old, he threw the three last into the fire. As to religion, his opinions were, that Christianity is absurd; Judaism, the religion of children; and Muhammadanism, the religion of swine. The best edition of his works is that of Venice, published in 1608. He is said to have died in 596 A.D., corresponding with 1199 A.D., but Lamprédio in his Universal Biography says, that he died at Morocco in 1206 A.D.

Ibn-Sabbagh-al-Shafai, ابن صعب الشافعي, surname of Abú Nasr 'Abdúl-Bádín-Muhammad, author of the "Uddat-ul-'Alim Wát Tarkí-ul-Sálím." He died 1084 A.D., 477 A.H.

Ibn-Sad, ابن سعد, author of the Tabakát.

Ibn-Sina, ابن سينا, vide Abú Sina.

Ibn-Shahab-us-Zohri, ابن شهاب الزهري, an Arabian author who flourished during the Khilafát of 'Umar-ibn-'Abdul-Ans.

Ibn-Siraj, ابن سراج, whose proper name is Abú Bakr Muhammad, was an Arabian author, and died in 928 A.D., 316 A.H.

Ibn-Ukbe, ابن عقبة, surname of Jamal-uddín Ahmad, author of the "Umdat-ut-Tálib." He died 1424 A.D., 328 A.H.

Ibn-Ukda, ابن عقدة, vide Abú'l-'Abbás Ahmad-bin-Muhammad.

Ibn-ul-Arabi, ابن العربي, vide Ibn-Arabi.

Ibn-ul-Hajar, ابن الهمز, vide Im-Hajar.

Ibn-ul-Jasari-bin-Muhammad, ابن جساري, an Arabian author who died in the year 1430 A.D., 333 A.H.

Ibn-ul-Khashab, ابن خشب, whose proper name is Abú Muhammed 'Abdullah, was an excellent penman. He died at Baghdad in 1172 A.D., 567 A.H.

Ibn-ul-Rumi, ابن الرمزي, a famous Arabian poet who was contemporary with Avicenna. He is the author of a Diwán in Arabic.

Ibn-ul-Warda, ابن وردة, author of an Arabic history called "Mukhtásir Jéma-ut-Tawáríkh," a valuable general history from 1097 to 1543 A.D.

Ibn-us-Saleh, ابن الصالح, whose proper name is Abú 'Amrú Usmán-bin-'Abdur Rahman-as-Shahrsúri, author of a collection of decisions according to the doctrine of Sháfi'i, entitled "Fatáwá Ibn-us-Saleh." He died in 1244 A.D., 642 A.H.

Ibn-Yemín, ابن يمين, a celebrated poet, whose proper name was Amr Mahmúd, which see.

Ibn-Yunas, ابن يونس, astronomer to the Khalif of Egypt, who observed three eclipses with such care, that by means of them, we are enabled to determine the quantity of the moon's acceleration since that time. He lived about a century or more after Al-Batani.

Ibn-Zohr, ابن زهر, vide Abdul Malik Ibn-Zohr.

Ibn-Zuryk, ابن زريك, Tanúki, an author.

Ibrahim, إبراهيم, the patriarch Abraham.

Ibrahim, إبراهيم, an emperor of the Moors of Africa in the 12th century, who was dethroned by his subjects, and his crown usurped by 'Abdul Múmin.

Ibrahim, Sultan, إبراهيم السultan, emperor of the Turks, was the son of Ahmad (Ahkmat). He succeeded his brother Murád IV (Amarath) in February, 1640 A.D., 1049 A.H., and spent a great part of his reign in the war of Crete against the Venetians, but without any great success. He was assassinated for his debaucheries and repeated cruelties in 1649 A.D., 1059 A.H. His son Muhammed IV, succeeded him.

Ibrahim, إبراهيم, the son of Alashar, killed in 690 A.D., 71 A.H., in a battle fought between the Khalif 'Abdul Malik and Misás'b the brother of 'Abdullah, the son of Zúbar whose faithful friend he was.

Ibrahim, إبراهيم, the son of Ibrahim Mahrán, a very famous doctor of the sect of Sháfi'i, and author of several works.

Ibrahim Adham, إبراهيم ادهم, a king of Balkh, who retired from the world, became a Dervish and died between the years 875 and 880, aged 110 years. It is said that he saw in a dream, a man on the top of a house looking for something. He asked him, what he was looking for? The man replied, that he had lost his camel. What a fool you must be, said the king, to be looking for your camel on the roof of a house! The man rejoined, And what a fool you must be to look for God in the cares and troubles of a crown! Ibrahim from that day abdicated his throne, and became a wandering Dervish.

Ibrahim 'Adil Shah I, إبراهيم عادل شاه, Sultan of Bijápur, surnamed Abú'l Nasr, son of Ismail 'Adil Shah, succeeded his brother Mallú 'Adil Shah, on the throne of Bijápur in the Dakhán in 1535 A.D., 941 A.H. He married the daughter of 'Ala-uddín 'Imád Sháh, named Rabia Sultána in 1543 A.D., 960 A.H., reigned 24 lunar years and some months, and died in 1568 A.D., 965 A.H. He was buried at Kóki near the tombs of his father and grandfather, and was succeeded by his son 'Alí 'Adil Shah.

Ibrahim 'Adil Shah II, إبراهيم عادل شاه, of Bijápur, surnamed Abú'l Mansúr, was the son of Tahmásb the brother of 'Alí 'Adil Shah, who succeeded him in April, 1590 A.D., Safar, 988 A.H., being then only nine years of age. The management of public affairs was given to Kamál Khán Dakhání, and Chánd Bibi Sultána, widow of the late king, was entrusted with the care of the education of the minor monarch. For some time Kamál Khán behaved with due moderation in his office; but at length was guilty of some violence towards Chánd Sultána, who turned her thoughts to effect his destruction. She secretly sent a message to Hájí Kishwar Khán, an officer of high rank, who caused him to be murdered. After this event Kishwar Khán, by the support and patronage of Chánd Bibi, grasped the authority of the State, and ruled with uncontrolled sway, till he was assassinated. Akhás Khán next assumed the regency; but after some time he was seized by Diláwar Khán, who put out his eyes, and deprived him of all empire. He was expelled by the king in 1590 A.D., and his place was taken by himself confined in 1592 A.D. Ibrahim 'Adil Shah died after a reign of more than 38 lunar years in 1626 A.D., 1036 A.H., and was succeeded by his son Muhammad 'Adil Shah. The first building of any importance we meet at Bijápur, is the Ibrahim Rauza, the tomb of Ibrahim 'Adil Shah II. On a high-raised platform of stone, separated by a square, in the midst of which is a houz or fountain, stand the rousa and mosque opposite each other, and corresponding in size and contour. The tomb is most elaborately ornamented, the walls being covered
Ibrahim

with inscriptions from the Koran in raised stone Arabic letters, which formerly were gilt, on a blue ground, though now the colouring has worn away. The mosque also is a beautiful building.

Ibrahim Ali Khan, the new chief of Maleir Kotla is a minor of about 16 years of age (1872), and is receiving his education in the Wards' School at Umballa.

Ibrahim Ali Khan, nawab of Tonk, grandson of the famous Pindara chief Amir Khan. His father Muhammad 'Ali Khan was deposed by the British Government on account of the Lows massacre in 1867. He was installed as nawab of Tonk on the 19th January, 1871 by the British Government.

Ibrahim Astarabadi, an author who translated the Risala or "Kitab Hasana" of Abu'l Fatih Rasul Makki from the Arabic into Persian in 1561 A.D., 968 A.H.

Ibrahim Barid Shah, succeeded his father 'Ali Barid in the government of Ahmadabad Bidar about the year 1562 A.D., 970 A.H. He reigned seven years and died about the year 1569 A.D., 977 A.H. His brother Kasim Barid II, succeeded him.

Ibrahim Bayru, Malik. In the province of Behar there is a hillock called Pir Fakhri, on the top of which there is a tomb with Persian inscriptions in verse, intimating that Malik Ibrahim Bayru died in the reign of Sultan Firoz Shah on a Sunday in the month of Zil-hijja 763 A.H., which corresponds with January, 1363 A.D., but who he was we are not informed.

Ibrahim-bin-Aghlab, an Arabian captain who was appointed governor of Egypt and Africa by the Khalif Harun-al-Rashid in 800 A.D., 184 A.H. The descendants of this governor who settled in Africa bore the name of Aghlabia or Aghlabites, and formed a dynasty of princes who reigned there till the year 908 A.D., 296 A.H., when they were driven out by the Fatimites.

Ibrahim-bin-Ali, author of the work called "Majma-ul-Ansab," or the Genealogy of the different dynasties of Persia, till 1233 A.D., 630 A.H.

Ibrahim-bin-Hariri, author of the "Tarikh Ibrahim," an abridged history of India, from the earliest times, to the conquest of that country by the emperor Babar Shah, who defeated Sultan Ibrahim Husain Lodhi, king of Delhi, and became the founder of the Mughal dynasty. It was dedicated to Babar Shah in 1538 A.D., 934 A.H.

Ibrahim-bin-Muhammad-al-Halabi, Shaikh, author of a Persian work on Theology called "Akhd Sunna," and of the "Mulatta al-Abhar." This work, which is an universal code of Muhammadan law, contains the opinions of the four chief Mujtahid Imams, and illustrates them by those of the principal juriconsults of the school of Abu Hanifa. He died 1649 A.D., 956 A.H., vide Imam 'Alam-bin-'Ata.

Ibrahim-bin-Nayal, brother of Tughral Beg's mother, a chief who defeated Tughral Shah I, a prince of the Seljukian family, in battle, took him prisoner and blinded him. Ibrahim was murdered after some time in 952 A.D., 461 A.H., by Tughral Beg, the uncle of Tughral Shah.

Ibrahim-bin-Saleh, cousin of Harun-al-Rashid. A curious story is given of him in the Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society, No. 11, that when he died, Ma'ka al-Hind, the philosopher, restored him to life, and that Ibrahim lived long after this circumstance, and married the princess 'Ali Abbasa, daughter of Al-Mahdi, and obtained the government of Egypt and Palestine, and died in Egypt.

Ibrahim-bin-Walid II, a Khalif of the race of Umayya, succeeded his brother Yazid III, in 744 A.D., 126 A.H., and had reigned but seventy days, when he was deposed, and slain by Mu'awiya II, who ascended the throne in Syria.

Ibrahim Hussain, Khwaja, a celebrated calligrapher in the service of the emperor Akbar, who wrote a beautiful Nastaliq hand. He died in the year 1593 A.D., 1001 A.H., and Abdul Kadir Badawi found the chronogram of his death to be contained in his very name with the exception of the first letter in Ibrahim, viz., Alif.

Ibrahim Husain Lodi, Sultan, ascended the throne of Agra, after the death of his father Sikandar Shah Lodi in February, 1610 A.D., Zi-kada 915 A.H. He reigned 16 years, and was defeated and slain in a battle fought at Panipat with the emperor Babar Shah on Friday the 20th April, 1526 A.D., 7th Rajab, 932 A.H., an event which transferred the empire of Delhi and Agra to the family of Amir Taimur. From this battle we may date the fall of the Pathan empire, though that race afterwards made many efforts, and recovered it for a few years in the time of the emperor Humayun.

Ibrahim Husain Mirza, a son-in-law of the emperor Humayun, and the second son of Muhammad Sultan Mirza, who had four other sons besides him viz., 1st, Mohammad Husain Mirza, 2nd, Ibrahim Husain Mirza, 3rd, Musa'd Husain Mirza, 4th, Ulugh Mirza, who died in 1567 A.D., 974 A.H., and 5th, Shah Mirza. They were styled, "The Mirzas," and were, on account of their ill-conduct, confined in the Fort of Sambhal by order of the emperor Akbar. When that monarch marched in the year 1567 A.D., 975 A.H., for the purpose of subduing Malwa, they made their escape and sought an asylum with Chingis Khan, a nobleman at Baroach. They took Champanagar and Sirdar and also Baroach in 1569 A.D., 977 A.H., and created a great disturbance in the surrounding countries. Ibrahim Husain was taken prisoner in 1578 A.D., 981 A.H., and shortly after put to death by Mahkhsu Khan, governor of Multan, and his head sent to the emperor; who ordered it to be placed over one of the gates of Agra, (vide Gulrakh Begam) and caused his brother Musa'd Husain Mirza to be confined in the fort of Gwalior where he soon after died.

Ibrahim-ibn-Aghlab, a king of Barbary. This country was reduced by the Saracens in the Khilafat of Umar, and continued subject to the Khalif of Arabia and Baghdad till the reign of Harun-al-Rashid, who having appointed Ibrahim-ibn-Aghlab, governor of the western parts of his empire, then preferred the opportunity, first of assuming greater powers for himself than had been granted by the Khalif, and then erecting a principality altogether independent of the Khalifa. The race of Aghlab continued to enjoy their new principality peaceably till the year 910 A.D., 298 A.H., during which time they made several descents on the island of Sicily, and conquered a part of it. About this time, however, one Obeidullah surnamed 'Al-Mahdi, rebelled against
Ibrahim Khan Fatha Jang, was a relation of the celebrated Nur Jahán Begam, whose mother's sister he had married. When Kasim Khán the grandson of Shaikh Salím Chishtí was recalled to court from the government of Bihar in the twelfth year of the emperor Jahángír 1616 A.D., 1026 A.H., Ibrahim Khán was appointed governor of that province with the rank of 4000. He was killed at Dacca 1623 A.D., 1032 A.H., in battle against prince Khurrum (afterwards Shah Jahán) who had rebelled against his father Jahángír. His wife Rúh Parwáz Khánání lived to a great age, and died in the reign of the emperor 'Alamgír.

Ibrahim Khan Sur, son of Ghásí Khán, governor of Bayána, was the brother-in-law of Muhammad Sháh 'Adilí, whose sister he had married. He raised a considerable army and took possession of Dohlí and Agrah on the 28th February, 1565 A.D., 966 Jumáda I, 962 A.H. He had no sooner ascended the throne, than another competitor arose in the province of the Panjáb, in the person of Ahmad Khán, a nephew of the late Sheir Sháh. He defeated Ibrahim Khán in a battle, and the latter retreated to Sambhal, where Ahmad Khán took possession of Agrah and Dohlí, and assumed the title of Sikandar Sháh in May the same year. Ibrahim Khán was killed by Sulaimán, King of Bengal, in Orissa in a battle fought in 1667 A.D., 976 A.H., and is buried there. Amongst the incidents of the year 1565 A.D., 962 A.H., was the explosion in the fort of Agrah, when enormous stones and columns were sent flying several kís to the other side of the Jamna, and many people were destroyed. As the whole Fort was called Bádálgarh, the date was found in the words, "The fire of Bádálgarh."

Ibrahim Khawas, pupil of Abú 'Abdulláh Maghrábi who died 911 A.D. He was called Khawás, which means a basket-maker.

Ibrahim Kutb Sháh, was the son of Kuli Kutb Sháh, sovereign of Golkanda. On the death of his brother Jamshíd Kutb Sháh, the nobles of the court elevated his son Subhán Kutb, a child of seven years of age, to the throne; but as he was unable to wield the sceptre, Ibrahim was sent for from Bijána, where he then resided, and was crowned on Monday, the 28th of July, 1550 A.D., 12th Rajáb, 957 A.H. In the year 1565 A.D., 972 A.H., he, in conjunction with the other Muhammedan monarchs of the Dakhán, marched against Ramráj, the rásí of Bijána garh, who was defeated and slain, and his territories occupied by the conquerors. In 1571 A.D., 979 A.H., the fort of Réjmandrí was taken from the Hindás by Rafa't Khán, the general of Ibrahim; the following chronogram commemorates the date of its occurrence: "The temple of the infidels has fallen into our hands." Ibrahim Kutb Sháh, after a prosperous reign of 32 years, died suddenly on Thursday the 5th of June, 1581 A.D., 21st Rabí' II, 989 A.H., in the 51st year of his age, and was succeeded by his son Muhammad Kutb Sháh.

Ibrahim Mirzá, the son of Bahram Mirzá and grandson of Shah Isma'il Safví. His poetical name was Jahí. He was murdered by order of his grandfather.

Ibrahim Mirzá, Sultan, was the son of Sháhrukh Mirzá and grandson of Amr Taimír. He was governor of Fará during the life of his father, and died a few years before him in 1435 A.D., 839 A.H. After his death, his son 'Abdullah Mirzá succeeded him, and was killed in battle against Mirzá Abú Sa'id his cousin-german in 1451 A.D., 855 A.H.

Ibrahim Mirzá, his poetical name was Adam, which see.

Ibrahim Mirzá, the son of Mirzá Sulaimán of Badakhshán, was born in the year 1534 A.D., 941 A.H. When his father with the intention of conquering Balkh went to that country, prince Ibrahim accompanied him, and was taken prisoner in battle, and put to death by order of Pr Muhammad Khán, ruler of Balkh in the month of September, 1560 A.D., Zil-hijjah, 967 A.H.

Ibrahim Nayál, succeeded his father Burhán Nizám Sháh II. in the kingdom of Akhandagarh Dakhán in the month of April, 1598 A.D., Shában, 999 A.H., and was slain in action against the troops of Ibrahim Nizám Sháh II., of Bihár, after a reign of only four months in the month of August, 1598 A.D., Zil-hijjah, 1003 A.H. Mián Manjú, his Wazír, raised to the throne one Ahmad a boy, said to be of the Nizám Sháhí family.

Ibrahim Pasha, an adopted son of Muhammad 'Ali Pasha of Egypt, was born in 1789 A.D., and gave the first proofs of his gallantry and generalship in 1819 A.D., in quelling the insurrection of the Wahábís. He afterwards made several conquests. In 1848 A.D. when Muhammad 'Ali had sunk into absolute dotage, Ibrahim went to Constantinople, and was installed by the Porte as Viceroy of Egypt; but on the 9th November, 1848, he died at Cairo.

Ibrahim Sháh Sháriki, Sultan, ascended the throne of Jaunpúr, after the death of his brother Mubárík Sháh in 1402 A.D., 804 A.H. He was famous during his reign for the encouragement he afforded to literature; and we find that in those times of anarchy and confusion which prevailed in Hindústán, Jaunpúr became the seat of learning; as appears (says Firátá) from several works extant, dedicated to Ibrahim Sháh. He died in 1440 A.D., 844 A.H., after a long reign of upwards of 40 years. He was beloved in life, and he was regretted by all his subjects. His eldest son Mahmúd Sháh Sháriki succeeded him.

Ibrahim Sháh Pir, a Muhammedan saint whose tomb is in the district of Kach thirty miles above Lakpat. Vide Transactions Royal Asiatic Society, Vol. III., p. 558.

Ibrahim Sháikh, the son of Shaikh Músá, the brother of Shaikh Salím Chishtí. He served Akbar for several years in the military line, and when that emperor was proceeding to Kábúl after the death of his brother, Muhammad Hakím, Shaikh Ibrahim accompanied
Ibrahim, Shaikh, ibn-Mutri-us-Souri, author of the history of Alexander the Great and of Khizir in Arabic, called "Kitab Tarthif al-Jahadah Zulaykarnin al-Rumi," was written by him. This is one of those substructures of truth upon which Eastern nations have erected a large and romantic edifice of fable, much in the same manner as the tales of chivalry of the Middle Ages, which though fictitious, were partly attributed to real characters, as in the romances of the Knights of the Round Table and the Peers of Charlemagne.

Ibrahim Shirwani, Shaikh, ruler of Shirwan, who reigned about the beginning of the ninth century of the Hijra. Maulana Kashi flourished in his time and died in 1435 A.D.

Ibrahim Shaibani, Shaikh, of Kirman Shah, a pupil of Abu 'Abdullah Maghribi. He lived about the year 900 A.D.

Ibrahim, Sultan, the son of Sultan Mas'ud I of Ghazni, succeeded his brother Farrukhuddin in 1059 A.D., 487 A.H. He was a pious, liberal and just prince. In the first year of his reign he concluded a treaty of peace with Sultan Sanjar, the Seljukian, at the same time his son Mas'ud espoused the daughter of Malikshah, sister to Sultan Sanjar, and a channel of friendship and intercourse was opened between the two nations. He afterwards came to India and took several forts and obtained the title of conqueror by the extent of his victories. Sultan Ibrahim had 36 sons and 40 daughters by a variety of women, the latter of whom he gave in marriage to learned and religious men. He died after a reign of more than forty years in 1098 A.D., 492 A.H., aged 76 lunar years, and was succeeded by his son Sultan Mas'ud II or III. According to the work called "Tarik Guzida" he reigned 30 years and died in the year 1088 A.D., 481 A.H.

Ibrat, the poetical name of Ahmad 'Ali Khan, cousin of Nawab Sa'dat Khan Zafar Khan.

Ibrat, the poetical title of Mir Zaya-uddin, a poet, who wrote the first part of the story of Padmawat in Urdu verse, and died; consequently the second part was written by Ghulam 'Ali 'Ibrat, and finished in the year 1796 A.D., 1211 A.H., the chronogram of which he found to contain the words "Tasnim Doa'ir."

Ibrat, the poetical name of 'Abdul Mannan, which see.

Ibrat, the poetical name of Ahmad, a musician of Delhi, who, from the instructions that he received from Mirza 'Abdul Kadir Bedil, became an excellent poet. He at first had assumed "Mafatun" for his poetical name, but afterwards changed it for "Ibrat." He was a contemporary of Nasir 'Ali Khan, poet, and was living about the year 1688 A.D., 1100 A.H.

Ibrat, the poetical title of Mir Ziauddin, author of the first portion of the story of Padmawat in Urdu verse. He died about the year 1795 A.D. Vide Padmawat.

Idris or Adris-bin-Hisam-uddin, Mulla, author of the history called "Tarikh Haqiq Baha'i" or the Eighth Paradise, containing the Memoirs of the most illustrious characters of the Muhammadan religion, who flourished from 1461 to 1506 A.D.

Idrisi, also called Sharif-al-Idrisi-al-Sikili, author of a system of Arabian geography, composed in 1153 A.D. He is said to be one of the most eminent Arabic geographers and descendant of the royal family of the Idrisites. He was born at Ceuta or Sibila (Civitas) in the year 1090 A.D. The title of the above work is "Nuzhat-al-Mushatik," and it has been translated into Latin by several authors.

Iftikhar Khan, title of Sultan Husain, the eldest son of Mir 'Abdul Hadi, entitled Asif Khan Mir Bakhtiar, who died at Balkh in the 20th year of the emperor Shah Jahangir, 1647 A.D., 1057 A.H. In the first year of Alamgir, Sultan Husain was honored with the title of Iftikhar Khan. Some time before his death he was appointed Faujdar of Jumpan, where he died in 1681 A.D., 1092 A.H.

Iftat Bano, daughter of the emperor Jahangir. Her mother was the daughter of Sa'id Khan of Kashghar. She died at the age of 3 years.

Ihsan, the poetical name of Mirza Ihsanullah, commonly known by the title of Nawab Zafar Khan, who at one time was governor of Kabul when the poet Muhammad Ali Saeed of Persia came to see him there. He died in 1662 A.D., 1073 A.H., and is the author of a Diwan in Persian.

Ihsan, the poetical name of 'Abdur Rahman Khan of Dakh, who wrote excellent poetry in Urdu, and died some time after the year 1844 A.D., 1260 A.H.

Ihsan, the poetical title of a Hindoo named Chunn Lai, who was living at Agra in 1760 A.D., 1174 A.H.

Ihtisham Khan, title of Shaikh Farid of Fatehpur Sikri, the son of Kutub-uddin Shaikh Khuban. He served under the emperors Jahangir, Shah Jahangir and Alamgir; and was raised to the rank of 3000. He died in 1664 A.D., 1075 A.H.

Ijad, the poetical name of Mir Muhammad Ihsan, who died in the year 1721 A.D., 1133 A.H.

Ika Pandit, a Maratha who, in the time of Shah Alam and Madho Rao Scindia, held the appointment of the Subadarship of the fort of Agra.

Ikbal Khan, was the son of Zafar Khan, the son of Firoz Shah Tughlaq. He defeated Nasrat Khan and ascended the throne of Delhi about the beginning of the year 1400 A.D., 802 A.H., and was slain in a battle against Khizr Khan, the governor of Multan, in November, 1405 A.D., 19th Jamadi I, 808 A.H. After his death Sultan Mahmud Shah, who was defeated by Amir Timur and had fled to Gujarat and then to Kanauj, returned on the invitation of Danial Khan Lodhi who commanded at Delhi, and took possession of the empire.

Ikbal-uddaula Muhsin Ali Khan, the son of Shams-uddaula Ahmad 'Ali Khan, the son of Nawab Sa'dat 'Ali Khan of Lucknow. He sailed for England to claim the throne of Audh in January, 1838, A.D., and after trying in vain to obtain the recognition of his claim in England, determined upon
passing the remainder of his days in a life of sanctity in Turkish Arabia. He is the author of the work called "Iktbal Firang."

Ikhlas Khan Husain Beg, اخلاص خان حسین بیگ, a nobleman of the reign of the emperor Shah Jahán who died in the year 1639 A.D., 1049 A.H.

Ikhlas Khan Ikhlas Keish, اخلاص خان اخلاص کیش, was a Hindú of the tribe of Khattari of Lahore. He was well-versed in Persian, and served under the emperor Alamgir, who conferred on him the above title. In the time of Farrukh-siyar he was raised to the rank of 7,000. He wrote the history of that emperor and called it "Badshah Nama." See Kishun Chand.

Ikram Khan, اکرم خان, the son of Isálm Khán and Ládí Begam, the sister of Abú'l Fazl, the prime minister of the emperor Akbar. Vide Isálm Khán.

Ikram Khan, اکرم خان, title of Sayyad Hasan, an amir, who served under the emperor Alamgir, and died in 1661 A.D., 1072 A.H.

Ikram Ali, اکرم علی, author of the Urdu "Akhwán-us-Safá," which he translated from the Persian in the year 1810 A.D., 1225 A.H.

Ikramuddaula, اکرم الدوّلہ, the brother of 'Alí Náki Khán, the prime minister of Wajid 'Alí Sháh, king of Lakhnau, died August 1869, A.D.

'Ikríma, اکریما, son of Abú Jahl.

'Ikríma, اکریما, vide Akrima.

Iksir, Mirza, اکسر میرزا, vide Aksfr.

Ilah Wirdi Khan, اهل وردی خان, vide Alah Wirdi Khan.

Ilah Yar Khan, اهل یار خان, an author who, according to the work called "Khulásat-ul-Asha'ir," died in 1538 A.D., 946 A.H.

Ilahi, Mir, اهلی میر, name and poetical title of a person who was a descendant of the Sayyads of Rashidábéd in Humdán. He came to India in the latter part of the reign of Jahángir, and served under his son Shah Jahán. He is the author of a biography called "Khazina Ganj Ilahi," and of a Diwán containing amorous songs. The author of the "Mirat Jahan" says, he died in 1648 A.D., 1057 A.H., and from a chartogram which Ghulám Kashmír wrote at his death, it appears that he died in 1654 A.D., corresponding with 1064 A.H.

Ilahi, Shaikh, اهلی شاہک, a philosopher of Bayána, who in the time of Sháh Sháh, king of Delhi, made a great stir by introducing a new system of religion. He called himself Imám Mahdí, who according to the Sha'ís, is still living and is to conquer the world. Having raised a great disturbance in the empire, he was in the year 1547 A.D., 954 A.H., scourged to death by order of that emperor.

Ildiguz, Atabak, الدیگوز, was a Turkish slave, sold to Sultan Mas'ud, one of the Saljuquí princes. He is said to have so completely established himself in the favor of his royal master, that he advanced him to the highest stations in the kingdom; and the able manner in which Ildiguz executed every duty that was assigned to him, led at last, not only to his being charged with the education of one of the young princes, which gave him the title of Atabak or Atabeg, but to his marriage with the widow of Tughraí II (the brother of Mass'ud, and nephew of Sultan Sanjar), and within a short period he became the most powerful noble of the Persian empire. He died at Hamdán in 1179 A.D., 568 A.H., in the reign of Arsalán Sháh, and left his power and station to his eldest son Atábak Muhammad.

List of the Atábaks of the race of Ildiguz.

| Atábak Ildiguz | …………………… | died 1179 |
|----------------|----------------|-----------|
| Muhammad, son of Ildiguz | ………… | 1168 |
| Kízál Arsalán, son of Ildiguz | ………… | 1191 |
| Abú Bakr, son of Muhammad | ………… | died 1210 |
| Muzaffar, son of Muhammad | ………… | defeated 1225 |

by Sultan Jalál-ud-dín of Khwánum, and died some time after. He was the last of the Atábaks of the race of Ildiguz who reigned in Azurbéjan.

Ilham, ایلام, vide Malíl.

Ilmas 'Ali Khan, ایلام علی خان, the celebrated rich and powerful eunuch of the Court of Nawáb Asíf-uddaula. He died in 1808 A.D.

Ilitmirsh, ایلتمیرش, vide Altamish.

'Imad-al-Katib or Imad-uddin-al-Katib, عیاد الکتیب, that is, 'Imád the Secretary, was the surname of Muhammad, the son of 'Abdulláh, the son of Samad, also called Isfahání. He was a celebrated author, and has written in Arabic the history of Sálíh-uddín (Saladin) the Sultan of Egypt and Syria, in seven volumes, entitled "Bark-ush-Shámi," the Lightning of Syria. He died 1201 A.D., 597 A.H.

'Imádi, اسماعیل, surname of Jamál-uddín-bin-'Imad-uddín Hanafi, author of the Arabic work called "Fusul-ul-'Imádi."

'Imad Fakih Kirmani, خواجہ علاء الدین کرمی, a Muhammedan doctor who lived in the time of Sháh Shujá's of Shiráz. His death is mentioned in the "Jawáhir-ul-Asha'ir" to have happened in 1391 A.D., 798 A.H., but according to the poets Iláhí and Dáshal Sháh he died in the year 1371 A.D., 773 A.H., which appears to be correct. Iláhí also mentions that he had seen 12,000 verses of his contemporaries, and that he is the author of the works called "Muhabbat Náma," and "Mehnat Náma," adding that he wrote in all a "Panj Gani," that is to say five Masnavís or Poems. It is mentioned in the "Háfi-bu-Siar," that Khwája 'Imád had a cat that would stand up to prayers with him, and do what he did. This was believed by Sháh Shujá's to be a miracle of the Khwája; but Khwája Háfs who was his contemporary, and would not take it for a miracle, but a deceit of the doctor, wrote a gházal on that occasion; the following is the translation of a couplet from the same: "O thou charming bird, where art thou going, stand still, and be not proud (or think thyself to be safe) because the cat of the saint says prayers." 'Imád Khwája was buried at Kirman, the place of his nativity.

'Imad Khwája, خواجہ علاء الدین, vide 'Imád Fakih.

'Imad Shah, ایلام شاہ, vide Imádul Mulk, commonly called Fathá-illáh.

'Imad-uddin Katib, عیاد الدین کاتیب, vide 'Imád-al-Katib.

'Imad-uddín, اسماعیل, surname of Kara Arsalán-bin-Dádéh-bin-Sukmán-bin-Aták. Náfí-uddín Mahmúd was his son, to whom Salah-uddín (Saladin) the Sultan of Egypt gave the city of 'Amid or Kara Amid, 1180 A.D., 579 A.H.
'Imad-uddin, author of a poem called the "Gulasta" or the Nosegay, which he composed in 1664 A.D., 1075 A.H. He was a native of India.

'Imad-uddin, author of the history of the Saljukides.

'Imad-uddin Zangi, the son of Asfar, was one of the Atabaks or ruling ministers under the latter princes of the Saljukian race. He was the first of that branch that had the government of Mousal. He received the governorship of that province in 1127 A.D., 521 A.H., from Sultan Muhammad, the son of Sultan Malikshah Saljuki, reigned 19 years, and was murdered by one of his slaves in 1146 A.D., 540 A.H.

The following is a list of the princes of this race:
